stem: A 28-year-old client with a T4 spinal cord injury (SCI) reports a sudden, throbbing headache. Based on the documentation, complete the bowtie by selecting the most likely condition, two actions the nurse should take, and two parameters the nurse should monitor.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content:
Situation: Acute hypertensive crisis in a client with paraplegia.
Background: T4 complete SCI (3 years ago). Client is in the rehab unit.
Assessment: Skin is flushed and sweating above the level of injury; cool and pale below. Client is extremely anxious.
Recommendation: Immediate assessment for noxious stimuli.

tabs.title: Spinal Cord Injury Monitoring
tabs.content:
Assessment ItemCurrent FindingInterpretation
Blood Pressure210/115 mmHgSevere Hypertension
Heart Rate52 bpmReflex Bradycardia
Physical ExamDistended bladder noted on palpationPotential Trigger
NeurologicalIntense headache; Blurred visionSymptomatic Crisis

tabs.title: Nursing Notes
tabs.content: 14:00 - Client reported difficulty with indwelling catheter drainage. 14:15 - Catheter found to be kinked under the wheelchair frame. 14:20 - BP increased rapidly.

actionOptions.text: Immediately elevate the head of the bed (HOB) to 90 degrees
Check the urinary catheter for kinks or distention
Place the client in a flat, supine position
Perform a digital rectal exam immediately

parameterOptions.text: Mental status and orientation every 4 hours

rationale.correct: Autonomic Dysreflexia (c2) occurs in SCI at or above T6. The trigger (kinked catheter/distended bladder) sends a message that causes mass sympathetic discharge (Hypertension), while the brain attempts to compensate with parasympathetic signals (flushing, sweating, bradycardia). The priority is to lower BP by sitting the client up (a1) and removing the noxious stimulus (a2). Monitoring BP (p1) and HR (p2) is essential since severe HTN can lead to seizure or stroke.
clinicalPearls: Common triggers: Bladder distention (number one), fecal impaction, or tight clothing/shoes.
The nursing response is 'Up, Loosen, Look': Up with HOB, Loosen clothing, Look for the trigger.
Flushing occurs ABOVE the injury; goosebumps/pale skin occurs BELOW.

questionTrap.trap: Calling for an antihypertensive before sitting the patient up.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Sitting the patient up at 90 degrees creates orthostatic pressure drop immediately. This is the FIRST action before any meds or assessments.

mnemonic.title: AD Response
mnemonic.expansion: Head of bed UP. Bladder Check. Bowel Check.
